title.native: 映像研には手を出すな！
title.romaji: Eizouken ni wa Te wo Dasu na!

description:
First year high schooler Midori Asakusa loves anime so much, she insists that "concept is everything" in animation. Though she draws a variety of ideas in her sketchbook, she hasn't taken the first step to creating anime, insisting that she can't do it alone. The producer-type Sayaka Kanamori is the first to notice Asakusa's genius. Then, when it becomes clear that their classmate, charismatic fashion model Tsubame Mizusaki, really wants to be an animator, they create an animation club to realize the "ultimate world" that exists in their minds.

(Source: Crunchyroll)
synonyms: Don't mess with the Motion Picture Club!
Hands off the Motion Picture Club!

tags.name: Drawing
tags.description: Centers around the art of drawing, including manga and doujinshi.

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Cute Girls Doing Cute Things
tags.description: Centers around female characters doing cute activities, usually with little to no emphasis on drama and conflict.

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Surreal Comedy
tags.description: Prominently features comedic moments that defy casual reasoning, resulting in illogical events.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Educational
tags.description: Primary aim is to educate the audience.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Filmmaking
tags.description: Centers around the art of filmmaking.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

node.description: Praised nationwide for his work as a character designer on [Osomatsu-san](https://anilist.co/anime/21261/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. [Official Website](http://chelmico.com/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6fbKSFZar4fvmBhN1hkEww) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/chelmico_offi) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/chelmico/) | [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/chelmico) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chelmico) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chelmico)

__Genres:__ Hip hop, J-rap, J-pop, Electropop
__Years Active:__ 2014–present
__Label:__ unBORDE (Warner Music Japan)

__Introduction:__
'chelmico' is a female rap duo from Japan. Their name is a portmanteau of the duo's names, Ra**chel** and Ma**miko**.

__Members:__
- [Rachel Watashiga](https://anilist.co/staff/163146/Rachel-Watashiga) (渡賀レイチェル), also known by stage name Rachel) – rapper
- [Mamiko Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/163147/Mamiko-Suzuki) (鈴木真海子, also known by stage name Mamiko) – rapper

name.native: 神様、僕は気づいてしまった

node.description:
__[Website](https://sp.wmg.jp/kamiboku/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/_kamiboku)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKHSCfxL1zWDfxeD60z6Hpg)__

__Formed:__ 2016

__Introduction:__
Kami-sama, Boku wa Kizuite Shimatta, alternatively internationally known as Kami-sama, I have noticed, or otherwise known by their abbreviation Kamiboku, is a Japanese  four-piece rock band under record label Atlantic Japan (2017-)

__Members:__
- [Dokono Dareka](https://anilist.co/staff/274607) – vocalist, guitarist
- [Heito Higashino](https://anilist.co/staff/274610/Higashino-Heito) – guitarist
- [Ryuushin Izumi](https://anilist.co/staff/163148/Ryuushin-Izumi) – bassist, in-charge of lyrics and composition
- [Ren](https://anilist.co/staff/274608/Ren) – drummer

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/松本憲生)

Originating from Tatsunoko's animators training institute, where he met [Atsushi Wakabayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105805/). Though primarily an action animator, he’s demonstrated impressive range elsewhere like in his scenes for [Haibane Renmei](https://anilist.co/anime/387/) and [Kaguya-hime](https://anilist.co/anime/16664/). He has the reputation of a fast and disciplined worker. [Toshiyuki Inoue](https://anilist.co/staff/103724/) said that he must have a “secret” for producing such a large volume of superb cuts.

Though one of his earliest assignments was as an in-betweens checker for [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/), his first major job was on [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), working under the director of the series, [Kazuhiro Furuhashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100655/). He would collaborate with Furuhashi again on Rurouni Kenshin, [You’re Under Arrest](https://anilist.co/anime/1577/), and [Hunter x Hunter](https://anilist.co/anime/136/). Around this time Matsumoto was also mentored by [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on [Irresponsible Captain Tylor](https://anilist.co/anime/569/).

Matsumoto’s character animation is loose and full of smears, often looking like featureless masses in individual frames. He draws smoke without highlights, a tendency that earned the nickname “Norio smoke” and has been imitated by animators like [Shingo Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/114914/) and [Kenichi Kutsuna](https://anilist.co/staff/116007/). He occasionally storyboards his own scenes as he did for the 12th episode of [Birdy Decode:02](https://anilist.co/anime/5074/), the [third Naruto movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2144/), and episodes 31 & 85 of [Rurouni Kenshin](https://anilist.co/anime/45/). Prefers battles that take place in wide-open spaces with lots of forward momentum and background movement. Influenced by [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/) and [Takashi Nakamura](https://anilist.co/staff/102031/), and has adapted elements of their approach for a wider audience.

Whenever he serves as animation director on an episode, he does a lot of the key animation work himself. He also soloed the 7th episode of [Eat-Man](https://anilist.co/anime/1704/) and the [Kuragehime](https://anilist.co/anime/8129/) ED. He failed attempting to solo the 39th episode of You’re Under Arrest, and requested his name not be on the telop despite animating the vast majority of the episode.

Famous for his work on the [Naruto](https://anilist.co/anime/20/) franchise, in which he often collaborated with Atsushi Wakabayashi.

As a well known animator with a wide network of connections, he regularly helps and receives help from his friends.

(Source: Animators Wiki)
Praised nationwide for his work as a character designer on [Osomatsu-san](https://anilist.co/anime/21261/).
